results.title: Grand Théâtre Fantasmagorique shadow play set
results.brief_description: Shadow play sets used decorative paper puppets to cast short fables and fairytales. Popular in China for over 2000 years, they were later merged with other innovations, like magic lanterns, to project ghoulish phantasmagoria shows.

constellations_primary.name: Spooky shadows
constellations_primary.description: Hellish and hilarious vampires connect pioneering German cinema to contemporary New Zealand comedy with a quick detour into small town strangeness.

results.description:
Shadow puppetry has been popular in China for more than 2,000 years. Invented to entertain Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty, shadow plays were transported to Europe by travellers in the mid-18th century. There they were known as ombres chinoises (Chinese shadows) and were adapted to tell European stories. Puppeteer François Dominique Séraphin made them popular when he presented them in Paris in 1776, and by 1781 he was dazzling the court at the Palace of Versailles. Even Marie Antoinette admired his work.

Shadow play sets like this one used decorative paper puppets to cast short fables and fairytales. Later they were merged with other innovations, like magic lanterns, to project ghoulish phantasmagoria shows.
description_for_label:
Shadow puppetry has been popular in China for more than 2,000 years. Invented to entertain Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty, shadow plays were transported to Europe by travellers in the mid-18th century. There they were known as ombres chinoises (Chinese shadows) and were adapted to tell European stories. Puppeteer François Dominique Séraphin made them popular when he presented them in Paris in 1776, and by 1781 he was dazzling the court at the Palace of Versailles. Even Marie Antoinette admired his work.

Shadow play sets like this one used decorative paper puppets to cast short fables and fairytales. Later they were merged with other innovations, like magic lanterns, to project ghoulish phantasmagoria shows.

results.title: Gone Home
results.brief_description: When Katie returns home from overseas, she finds her house deserted and her family gone. That’s just one horror trope that Gone Home uses to mislead players as Katie searches the house for her family in this walking simulator.

constellations_primary.name: Teens, zines and 90s scenes
constellations_primary.description: Exploring representations of teen life and culture.

results.description:
When Katie returns home from overseas, she finds her house deserted and her family gone.

That’s just one horror trope that Gone Home uses to mislead players as Katie searches the house for her family. Unlike typical games, Gone Home features minimal activity and was an early ‘walking simulator’, with the story unfolding at the player’s own pace as they examine notes and objects, rather than relying on traditional exposition.

Developed by indie studio Fullbright, Gone Home was highly praised by critics and fans for its unique style and positive representation of LGBTQIA+ themes.
description_for_label:

results.title: Glass cinema slides
results.brief_description: These glass slides advertise films that charted the change from silent to sound cinema, as well as the changing face of cinema when the Motion Picture Production Code was established.

constellations_primary.name: Wearing the pants, ladies who lead
constellations_primary.description: The pre-code 1932 feature, A Bill of Divorcement, a glass cinema slide of which features in the glass cinema slide display, stars John Barrymore and Katharine Hepburn in her screen debut.

results.description: Hollywood studios spent a lot of money transitioning to talkies. To recoup the cost, they produced salacious films to attract big audiences. People certainly responded – including conservative groups, who pressured studios to protect family values. The Motion Picture Production Code was established in 1930 as a response but wasn’t enforced until 1934. These glass slides advertise films that charted the change from silent to sound cinema, including A Bill of Divorcement (1932), which flouted the production code by exploring a marriage breakdown, as well as John Ford’s The World Moves On (1934), the first film to receive a Motion Pictures Producers and Distributors of America (now MPAA) certificate under the new Production Code.
description_for_label: Hollywood studios spent a lot of money transitioning to talkies. To recoup the cost, they produced salacious films to attract big audiences. People certainly responded – including conservative groups, who pressured studios to protect family values. The Motion Picture Production Code was established in 1930 as a response but wasn’t enforced until 1934. These glass slides advertise films that charted the change from silent to sound cinema, including A Bill of Divorcement (1932), which flouted the production code by exploring a marriage breakdown, as well as John Ford’s The World Moves On (1934), the first film to receive a Motion Pictures Producers and Distributors of America (now MPAA) certificate under the new Production Code.

results.title: Giovanni Pastrone
results.brief_description: Giovanni Pastrone was a director, producer, actor and inventor who pioneered the use of diffused lighting, panoramas, grandiose sets, miniature models and a moving camera. All of these elements were on show in his epic 1914 film, Cabiria.

constellations_primary.name: Tracking cinema
constellations_primary.description: A constellation looking at the evolution of the tracking / dolly shot.

results.description: Giovanni Pastrone was a director, producer, actor and inventor who pioneered the use of diffused lighting, panoramas, grandiose sets, miniature models and a moving camera. All of these elements were on show in his epic 1914 film, Cabiria. The film broke new artistic ground by using special effects to re-create the eruption of Mount Etna and the naval battle of Syracuse, but its biggest legacy is the ‘Cabiria’ shot: the tracking shot. Pastrone mounted a camera on a dolly to trail the action in a scene, and this new technique was quickly adopted by filmmakers at the time.
description_for_label: Giovanni Pastrone was a director, producer, actor and inventor who pioneered the use of diffused lighting, panoramas, grandiose sets, miniature models and a moving camera. All of these elements were on show in his epic 1914 film, Cabiria. The film broke new artistic ground by using special effects to re-create the eruption of Mount Etna and the naval battle of Syracuse, but its biggest legacy is the ‘Cabiria’ shot: the tracking shot. Pastrone mounted a camera on a dolly to trail the action in a scene, and this new technique was quickly adopted by filmmakers at the time.

results.title: Ginger cinema slide
results.creator_credit: Fox Film Corporation and Lewis Seiler
results.credit_line: ACMI has endeavoured to contact the owners of these objects since their deposit in 2015. Unfortunately this has been unsuccessful. We would welcome any information to identify the owners.
results.brief_description: Two glass sheets: one glass only and the other with slide imagery which has a monochromatic emulsion that has then been hand painted with coloured pigments or dye. TEXT on the slide reads: A lovable Spitfire Ginger with Jane Withers and Jackie Searl Gunn Slide for General Exhibition The two sheets of glass are held together using Gunn’s Slide branded tape: Gunn’s Slide, 9 Collins Place Melb. Cent. 2736,
